Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I stare at my screen, the code review comments blinking like warning lights. “Performance issues—needs refactoring.” My team expects clean, efficient code, and I pride myself on delivering it. But this new feature is tangled, and fixing it will take hours I hadn’t planned for. I glance at the calendar. Saturday is the free vaccine clinic at the community center, and I promised to help organize the lines and answer questions. As a citizen, I want to do my part—pay my taxes, follow the rules, and show up when my community needs me. My tax documents are already sorted, but this clinic is a one-time chance to make a difference. My manager pings me: “Can you address the review comments by Monday?” I feel the pressure mounting from both sides. My team needs me to deliver quality work, but my neighbors are counting on volunteers. I sit at my desk, torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which responsibility I’ll have to let down.
